Title: the itchy brain simulation

Penny: Hey, can I ask you a question?
You’ve had this dart board since I’ve known you, but I’ve never seen you play.
What window?
Ooh, what are you gonna get?
Aw, did she hate you?
No, if it was a spider, Lenny would’ve flipped out.
Yeah, it’s freaking me out. I’m gonna go.
Yeah, hang on, just give me sec.
I scraped gum off the bottom of that table. Only ’cause my manager saw me put it there.
I don’t know why but I always pictured her as Indian.
I’m gonna go talk to her.
I’m not gonna say anything. I just want to check her out. Because she hurt my friend. My Indian friend. Who’s racist now?
Yeah, well, you’re short.
Hey, can I start you off with something to drink?
Okay. Um, you’re Lucy, right? I’m a friend of Raj Koothrappali’s. Actually Amy recognized you.
Oh, you know, he’s good.
Yeah, this is none of my business. But why did you break up with him in an e-mail?
Yeah, I get that. I’ll go get you your water. When you say easier, you mean easier for you, right? ‘Cause it certainly didn’t make it easier for him.
I’m sorry, this is rude of me. I will go get that water. See, see, see, see. Just now you expressed your feelings to my face. How come you could do that with me, but not Raj?
You know what the worst part is? You’re sitting here, perfectly happy and he’s at home, a blubbering mess.
Well, I also said I was getting you water, but look at me still standing here. You know, I may be a bad waitress, but you are a bad person. Now, you want to hear the specials?
Hey, if you guys were hungry, why didn’t you order something at the restaurant?
Oh, that’s right. Nachos and a turkey club.
Well, I was too busy standing up for my friend to worry about your, I want to say salmon.
What do you mean how? What’s the big deal?
Okay, you guys are overreacting. Raj is gonna appreciate how I had his back.
What are you doing?
Sheldon’s not here. Why don’t you take the sweater off?
Which is?
Oh, my God! Is that sweater made of bees? Come on, take it off. I won’t tell.
Sweetie, every night you don’t kill him in his sleep, he wins.
Smile.
So you can send it to Princeton and get your money back.
There’s a girl at the Cheesecake Factory I can set you up with.
Leonard: Sure.
Oh, uh, we played, once. I broke a window.
That one over there.
Skee-Ball tickets?
Uh, if I still have them, they’re probably in the junk box.
Yup, oh, here you go.
Oh. I forgot about this. My aunt made it for me when I started college.
Why? Because I got an ugly, itchy sweater, and my brother got a car? No, I was her favorite.
Hmm, I think I got them all. Nope, they’re not in there.
No, no, no, I, I looked, and there’s, there’s, there’s no more tickets.
Okay, okay. I’m gonna show you what’s in the box. But just promise not to flip out.

Okay, Sheldon, I know I was supposed to return this DVD a long time ago, and I know we rented it on your card. But it’s been, like, seven years and clearly nothing bad has happened. So in-in-in-instead of being a giant pain in the ass like you always are, what if this one time you just tried staying calm?
I’m sorry. I’ll, I’ll take care of it.
I mean it, I’m going to.
And you’re going to stay calm?
How about that? Sheldon’s being reasonable.

So, when you say you’re not going to freak out about the DVD, here’s what that means. Don’t fixate on it. Don’t wake me up in the middle of the night. Or nag me through the door while I’m on the toilet.
When I broke my arm I used to stick a coat hanger down there. You ever try that? Maybe go in through the ear?
Well, I don’t know how to do that.
That’s stupid. Why?
I’m telling you, try the hanger.
You got it. If this sweater shuts you up, I’m gonna make a fortune selling them to everyone we know. Now all I need to do is head down to the video store and return the DVD.
Really?
No.
No.
It’s called proving a point.

Monday morning I’ll go downtown, look up the owner’s information and send him the DVD. Pay the late fee, and prove to Sheldon that you can have a problem and solve it without acting like a complete lunatic. Ah!

Well, Sheldon, it took me all morning, but I found the owner of the video store. And I am happy to report that he died peacefully in his sleep, drunk at the bottom of a pool. Anyway, there is no one to return the DVD to, so this issue is resolved. Ah! And I’d just like to point out that even though the sweater was uncomfortable, I didn’t use it as an excuse to antagonize everyone around me.
Or it’s resolved.
Oh, I’m just trying to find the stupid next of kin to this stupid video store owner so I can return the DVD and see the look on Sheldon’s stupid face when he sees that I didn’t let this get to me.
There’s a principle at stake.
Oh, I don’t know. Who cares? Look at me.
No, no, honey, if I take it off, Sheldon wins.
No, it’s, it’s almost done. I just, I have to find the next of kin, and send ’em the DVD and then just wait for someone with my complexion to die so I can get a skin graft.
What is that? What is that for?
Okay, Sheldon, I am out of options. Video store owner, Nursis Manookian, has no next of kin.

Oh, oh, no, no. It’s because I spent all afternoon at the Armenian church where his funeral mass was held. According to Father Solakian, no one attended. Luckily, my trip wasn’t a complete waste. I lit a candle and prayed for your death but I’m not Armenian, so it probably won’t work. This is over, right?
Listen to me, Sheldon. I am not going to Lebanon to return Super Mario Brothers the movie.
Why isn’t this bothering you? Isn’t your brain getting itchy? This is on your card. This could be ruining your credit score. Why isn’t this making you crazy?
What?
What?
Aaaah! I, you, how can, what!
Sheldon: Leonard, where are the Skee-Ball tickets?
Yeah, from when we went to the arcade three years ago? I finally decided what prize I want. Hurry up.
None of your business. But when you see me wearing a flower in my lapel later, you are most welcome to sniff it.
Oh, thank you. Here, get yourself an eraser for your troubles.
I seem to be a few tickets short. Are there more in the box?
Well, you barely looked. Let me see.
Leonard, let me look in the box.
Why would I flip out? Is it a spider? It’s a spider.
That seems like a reasonable request. Although so did, hey, Leonard, would you mind returning that DVD?
Okay.
I believe you.
I said I would.

Okay, first, talking to you while you’re on the toilet isn’t exactly a picnic for me either, okay? Remember, when you can hear me, I can hear you. And second, you completely disregard how uncomfortable unresolved issues are for me. It’s, it’s like, a, an itch in my brain I can’t scratch.
You wouldn’t make jokes if you could feel the way I feel.

How about this? I promise I won’t pester you about the DVD. You can defecate in peace. That’s a win for both of us. But, until this matter is resolved, I would like you to wear this sweater. With nothing underneath it.
You say it’s itchy and uncomfortable. I say situations like this make me feel the same way.
Put it on. Let’s share the experience.
Oh, did I forget to tell you? That store went out of business years ago.
How those nipples feeling, chief?
Gentlemen, please. Leonard is trying to walk a mile in my metaphorical shoes. He can’t walk in my actual shoes. He has the feet of a toddler.
I’m thinking about how one could use the fact that a rapidly rotating mirror turns virtual photons into real ones as a method of observing dark energy.
Yeah. It’s great you’re here. I’d love to get an engineer’s opinion.
This chair is squeaky. Now, do I fix it or get a new one?
Hey, that next of kin thing sounds pretty good.
I don’t know why that surprises you. I’m a grown man. As should be evident by this sport coat and very real flower in my lapel.
The more interesting question you should be asking is, what does this flower smell like?
There’s nothing to tell. Maybe I purchased a book entitled Don’t Sweat the Small Stuff and I followed its wise suggestions, one of which was stop and smell the flowers.
Please. Ha-ha, Oh.
How is it I can conceptualize a methodology of examining dark matter in the universe but can’t figure out how to fix a novelty squirt flower?
There’s probably a deep reason. Which I’d be happy to discuss with you over some peanut brittle in a can.
Well, you seem hot under the collar, or is that the sweater?
Oh, not necessarily. I suggest you look for long-lost relatives either in Armenia or Lebanon.
You know, it might be fun. You love hummus.
Leonard, I have something to tell you, but I want you to promise not to flip out.
Seven years ago, I found out the DVD was late and I paid for it.
I was going to mention it at the time, but then I thought, some day, this might be a teachable moment.
I know. And it wasn’t easy. Do you have any idea what it’s like to wait for years and never know if you’re going to finally get satisfaction?
Bernadette: Penny, can we please get our drinks?
Cool. At my lab, I performed ten laser capture micro-dissections.
I think that reason’s called racism.
Why? What are you gonna say?
You because you just called him your Indian friend.
We did, you never brought it.
So, how are you gonna tell Raj abut what you did?
Then you made her cry and leave.
If this girl hurt you so much, are you sure you want to see her again?
Well, if you’re sure you want to do this, it’s only coffee, just relax and see what happens.
I’d save that for the second date.
Amy: At work today, I did an in vivo stereotaxic surgery.
Oh, my gosh. That’s the girl that broke Rajesh’s heart.
You told Lucy he was a pathetic mess.
I must say, Sheldon, you’re handling this DVD business with an impressive amount of maturity.
Is there some kind of new coping mechanism you’re employing?
I’m gonna go with sad. So what’s the story with you and this DVD?
I think the real question is, why do you waste your time with cheap, childish pranks?
Lucy: Oh, I don’t know. I guess I thought it would be easier.
Any chance I can get a different waitress?
Oh, I thought you said he was okay.
I’m pretty good. Listen, I just wanted to apologize for breaking up with you in an e-mail.
Oh, uh, I’m kind of seeing someone.
Howard: So, you can never take it off?
Is the point that you’re an idiot?
And the man impersonating a bear would like everyone to know that only you can prevent forest fires.
You didn’t have Smokey the Bear in India?
You had to be taught not to play with cobras?
You know, you could reimburse the video store owner’s next of kin.
You can’t let her know you’re hurting. You know, the key is confidence.

Well, if I may, he has so little self-respect and is so desperate for the smallest crumb of affection, she could literally sleep with his own father in his own bed and post the video to YouTube, and he’d still buy her flowers and ask her to be his bride.
Raj: Not even to sleep?
So, how are you gonna return the DVD if the store went out of business?
I don’t get it.
No. Oh, is he anything like, uh, Mun-Mun the Mongoose? He taught us not to play with cobras.
You had to be taught not to burn down the forest?

What is wrong with you, Penny? You ruined any chance I had of getting back with Lucy. Now she knows I’m a desperate mess instead of just being pretty sure. (Phone text sound) It’s Lucy. She wants to meet for coffee. I love you, Penny.
Can I ask you guys a question? So, I’m seeing Lucy tomorrow night, and I’ve never hung out with someone who broke up with me. How do you do it?
Why is the key always confidence? How come it’s never love handles and flop sweat?
He’s right. But in my defence, if we could survive that, we could survive anything.
Well, can I say she looks nice?
Can I tell her I miss her?
Oh, can I show her an oil painting I made of us surrounded by our children and grandchildren?
Good, good. ‘Cause no matter how hard I try, I cannot get the twins to look alike.
Hello. Oh, it’s so good to see you.
Please, sit. I, uh, I got you a cappuccino. I remembered it was your favourite. I also got crumb cake, but I remembered it was my favourite and I ate it. Anyway, uh, how are you?
Well, and I ate all the crumb cake. We both made mistakes.
I’m so happy you asked me here, and I hope we can hang out again sometime. You know, as friends, lovemaking partners, whatever.
I think I know the answer to this, but just to be clear, it’s not me, right?
This is all your fault, I should’ve listened to Mun-Mun because I’ve been playing with a cobra and her name is Penny. Why are you so cruel? Do you enjoy my pain?
I love you, Penny.
Wow. You’re even prettier than Penny said. I can’t believe a girl like you doesn’t have a boyfriend.
I don’t believe you, you’re lying to me.
Oh, it’s okay. I have no morals and I’m desperately lonely. I’ll be the other man if you want a little something-something on the side.

I’m gonna go talk to her.

I’m not gonna say anything. I just want to check her out. Because she hurt my friend. My Indian friend. Who’s racist now?

Hey, can I start you off with something to drink?

Oh, I don’t know. I guess I thought it would be easier.
Yeah, I get that. I’ll go get you your water. When you say easier, you mean easier for you, right? ‘Cause it certainly didn’t make it easier for him.
Any chance I can get a different waitress?
I’m sorry, this is rude of me. I will go get that water. See, see, see, see. Just now you expressed your feelings to my face. How come you could do that with me, but not Raj?

Oh, I thought you said he was okay.

We did, you never brought it.
Oh, that’s right. Nachos and a turkey club.

Then you made her cry and leave.
Okay, you guys are overreacting. Raj is gonna appreciate how I had his back.
